intro: Adicea guadalupensis, commonly known as the Guadalupe morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family, characterized by its twining stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically blooms in the spring and summer, producing vibrant blue or purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its seeds are enclosed in a fibrous, capsule-like structure. Adicea guadalupensis is often found in rocky soils and can thrive in full sun to partial shade.
